resources.string: Downtown Rapid City is the perfect weekend escape. Stay in centrally located hotels with modern comfort or historic charm. Explore the numerous art galleries, fashionable boutiques and array of eateries. You will find great entertainment, from music to museums and plenty of fun for the whole family. Play in the fountains at Main Street Square, a place to make fun-filled memories. With ample hotel rooms, over 80 shops and 30 restaurants, head Downtown, year round.
Rapid City, South Dakota, is home to fantastic restaurants, great shops and an awesome night-life...and the friendliest people around.
Links, Images and Information used in this portion of the app are obtained from the official Downtown Rapid City website.
Roam Like A Buffalo â€“ There Is A Great Big World Outside Your Door

You can have it all, from adrenaline-charged outdoor activities to thoughtful cultural pursuits and all the heart-stopping scenery in between. When you stay in Rapid City, you are within an hours drive of six national parks and monuments and surrounded by a local culture that is rich with history and artistic expression. In this land where gemstones and natural wonders have been forming for eons, even the smallest roadside stand holds the promise of a big discovery.
Links, Images and Information used in this portion of the app are obtained from the official Visit Rapid City website, Things To Do webpage.

Rapid City is a prime location at the foot of the Black Hills which makes it the ideal place for all types of outdoor recreation and adventures. From leisurely hikes to kayaking to extreme mountain biking, you will find it all within the city limits of Rapid City.
Visit the official webpage of the City Parks
The park system as it is set up today came around in large part due to the Flood of 1972.

The 1972 Black Hills Flood devastated Rapid City and surrounding communities. More than ten inches of rain fell in just over six hours on June 9, 1972. The failure of the dam at Canyon Lake sent water rushing through Rapid City. Raging waters flowed through Rapid Creek and several other Black Hills streams, overflowing the stream beds and sweeping trees, buildings and automobiles and other debris downstream. After flood waters receded, 238 people were dead and over 3,000 injured.

Historic documents, newspaper articles, and websites show the civic history of the Flood Plain creation and preservation. A flood plain is an area of low-lying ground adjacent to a river, formed mainly of river sediments and subject to flooding. The 1972 Flood was a natural disaster where homes were destroyed, lives lost, and Rapid City forever changed.

In the years following the flood, the city government relocated hundreds of families and businesses off of the Rapid Creek flood plain. The land was then converted for parks and recreation usage to ensure the safety of future generations. The Rapid City Greenway encompasses approximately 1,000 acres.
More information about the history of the flood can be found at the Black Hills Knowledge Network site.
Links, Images and Information used in this portion of the app are obtained from the official Visit Rapid City website and the Black Hills Knowledge Network website.

Main Street Square takes up one acre in Downtown Rapid City. During the summer, an interactive fountain flows on an ambient setting. A roughlock waterfall and rain curtain also flow during the warm months. During the winter, the green lawn is turned into an ice skating rink measuring 7,200 square feet. Main Street Square hosts more than 200 events annually, and has private rental space available.

BCycle is an automated bike sharing system designed for use by many people for short trips around town. There are currently two stations: Main Street Square in Downtown Rapid City and on the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology Campus.
Links, Images and Information used in this portion of the app are obtained from the official Main Street Square in Downtown Rapid City website.
Tour The City Of Presidents In Downtown Rapid City

Visitors to historic downtown Rapid City are greeted by the City of Presidents, a series of life-size bronze statues of the past presidents of our nation located along the streets and sidewalks. Whether you are enjoying downtown shopping, dining or other attractions, you can enjoy these sculptures free.

The City of Presidents project began in 2000 to honor the legacy of the American presidency. Each of the sculptures is privately funded, and the pattern of placement was chosen to maintain a coherent structure and eliminate any sense of favoritism or political gain. The City of Presidents is also a part of the Rapid City Historic District Tour.
By clicking on the US Flag above you can scroll through the list of presidents and select any you wish to have more information on. Or view the Interactive Walking Guide below.
Links, Images and Information used in this portion of the app are obtained from the official Visit Rapid City website, City of Presidents webpage.
